newsitem.title: DUBAI: Iran's speaker nominated as presidential candidate.
newsitem.headline: Iran's speaker nominated as presidential candidate.

text.p: Iran's main conservative clergy group nominated Speaker of Parliament Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri as their candidate in next year's presidential elections, newspapers reported on Thursday.

They said the Combatant Clergy Association (CCA), whose members include almost all of Iran's top officials, unanimously backed Nateq-Nouri's nomination for the polls that will choose a successor to President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.
Rafsanjani, who is barred by the constitution from running for a consecutive third term, as well as Iran's spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei are members of CCA's central council.
Nateq-Nouri has in the past year kept a high profile in the media prompting widespread expectations that he would run, but he has not officially announced his candidacy.
The nomination is the second he received from an influential group in Iran. Earlier this week, he received the support of a conservative group of Shi'ite Moslem theologians in the holy city of Qom.

With the backing of the conservative clerical establishment and so far with no strong challenger, Nateq-Nouri remains the most prominant nominee for the presidency, Iran's top executive position after a 1989 consitutional reform removed the post of prime minister.

The hopes of radical groups were dashed as their strong candidate against Nateq-Nouri, former prime minister Mir Hosein Musavi, said he was not running. The pro-Rafsanjani centrists have not yet nominated a candidate although they were reportedly coordinating with other factions.
Nateq-Nouri, a Shi'ite cleric, is the leader of the majority conservatives in parliament who uphold a stricter interpretation of religious and social norms of the 1979 Islamic revolution.
